definition[0]: used to say that someone should do something because it is the best or most sensible thing to do
example[0]: You really ought to quit smoking.
example[1]: The company ought to be making changes in its marketing strategy.
example[2]: What sort of crimes ought the police to concentrate on?
example[3]: You were out enjoying yourself when you ought to have been studying.
definition[1]: used to make a suggestion about something you think is a good idea, especially in a social situation
example[4]: We ought to get together some time soon.
example[5]: You ought to meet him; he’s really nice.
example[6]: We ought to get her some flowers for her birthday.
definition[2]: used to say that someone should do something or something should happen, because it is morally right or fair
example[8]: You ought to be ashamed of yourself.
example[9]: The courts ought to treat black and white defendants in exactly the same way.
example[10]: Many people felt that America ought not to take part in the war.
definition[3]: used to say that you think something will probably happen, is probably true etc
example[11]: He left two hours ago, so he ought to be there by now.
example[12]: They ought to win – they’ve trained hard enough.
example[13]: That ought to be enough potatoes for eight people.
example[14]: New technology ought to make this easier.
explanation[0]: You say that someone ought to do something
explanation[1]: You say that someone ought to have done something
example[16]: You ought to have explained  (=but you did not)
explanation[2]: You say that someone ought not to do something
explanation[3]: You say that someone ought not to have done something
example[18]: She ought not to have gone  (=but she did go)
explanation[5]: You ask ought someone to do something
explanation[6]: You ask ought someone to have done something
example[22]: Ought we to have told them?
